Description: Beverly Enterprises Inc. agreed to pay the United States and the State of California $20 million to settle allegations that its former wholly owned subsidiary, MK Medical, violated the civil False Claims Act.

The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Company: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES-ARKANSAS, INC. DBA SALINE NURS
Info Source: Extracted from a download of OSHA's Enforcment Data downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_catalogs.php

Description: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest operator of nursing homes, agreed to pay $170 million to settle allegations that it defrauded Medicare by fabricating records to make it appear that nurses were devoting much more time to Medicare patients than they actually were.

Private Litigation Case Title: Katziff et al v. Beverly Enterprises Inc., et al.

Description: Beverly Enterprises Hawaii, Inc. paid restitution of $130,923, a penalty of $619,076 and costs of $200,000 in settlement of allegations of falsification of records, irregular patient prescription practices, and kickback schemes for medication and pharmacy services.
Beverly Enterprises agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle allegations of patient neglect at facilities it owned and operated.
Beverly Enterprises agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle allegations of patient neglect at facilities it owned and operated.
Williamsburg Nursing Home (owned by Beverly Enterprises, Inc.) agreed to pay $40,000 to settle allegations of negligence in connection with injury to two residents.

Beverly Enterprises pleaded no contest to felony elder abuse and agreed to pay $2 million in civil penalties to resolve allegations that it failed to meet required standards of care in its 60 nursing homes in California.  Among the quality of care problems cited by state nursing home regulators were patients suffering from major bed sores, dehydration, malnutrition, poor personal hygiene and improper medication.
